Award.AwardTitle: EAGER-NEON: Exploring Ecosystem Contributions of Microbial Diversity to the Vertical Atmosphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Little is known about airborne microbial communities (AMCs), which include bacteria and fungi. The project will sample the composition of AMCs at five altitudes above four natural ecosystem types in North America that are characterized by NEON core sites. A novel combination of tethered and launched balloon-borne samplers will be used to collect samples up to 25 km in the atmosphere. Within the ecosystems, samples over urban and non-urban areas will be collected. The characterization of this little know life zone will contribute to a basic knowledge of the life around us and help to better understand biosphere function and human impacts on it.

This exploratory research will sample bacteria, archaea, and fungi in the atmosphere. Validated aerial microbial samplers using balloon technology will be employed. Atmospheric measures will be compared with surface samples. Abundances will be quantified by genetic sequencing. NEON data will be used to determine soil microbes and dominant vegetation, which will be evaluated as predictors of AMCs. Descriptions of the data and hypothesis tests on the similarity of samples by ecosystem, altitude, season, and urbanization will be carried out using statistical methods common in vegetation community studies. Broader impacts, in addition to increasing basic knowledge, will include training opportunities for undergraduate honors students, pairing biology and engineering majors and targeted at under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Activities:

  • We collected samples to analyze airborne bacterial communities from three altitudes (150 m, 30 m and 2 m) in urban and rural locations in four ecoregions.  Rural locations were paired with NEON domain sites to leverage publicly-available datasets.  We conducted this sampling in May 2017, which included a total of 24 sites.  At all sites, we also collected soil samples and plant samples from the predominant community members. We successfully extracted DNA from all these samples to enable bacterial community analysis using molecular approaches.  (Photos 1 and 2: Sampling in Colorado and Michigan)
  • We collected airborne samples from all three altitudes at one urban and one rural location in Michigan in winter 2016/2017.
  • We piloted an approach to correct for contamination using field blank samplers as well as negative controls to accompany our extractions. We proposed a novel way to correct for contaminant sequences.
  • We designed, constructed and tested light-weight passive samplers that can be attached to a tethered helikite. This unique approach allowed us to sample airborne communities at multiple altitudes from stable locations and over the same timeframe.  (Photos 3: Sampler Design)
  • We designed, constructed and tested samplers and tracking systems that can be attached to a released-balloon sampling platform to enable sampling at higher altitudes. (Photo 4: Zero Pressure Balloon Test)
  • DNA extracts from all airborne community samples in both seasons, all soil samples and all plant samples are frozen and available for further analysis. 

Results

  • Our results demonstrate an effect of land use development on both near-surface and higher-altitude airborne bacterial communities. Development influences the connectivity between higher-altitude and near-surface airborne bacteria. This suggests that land use change can have a significant effect on processes of bacterial dispersal, which may influence ecosystem-level functions, such as biogeochemical cycling or response to disturbance. (Photo 5: Conceptual Diagram)
  • Higher altitude samples represent a regional pool of microorganisms. In Michigan, higher altitude air above developed areas serves as a mechanism to distribute bacteria associated with human activities. Near-surface airborne communities (< 2 m) carry distinctive signatures of local airborne sources, but share similarities with higher altitude communities.
  • Our results also demonstrate that soil bacterial communities in urban systems follow the same convergence patterns that occur in other communities and processes. Despite the ecoregion-of-origin, urban soil bacterial communities remained similar. This pattern is driven by increases in organic matter, nitrogen content and moisture in urban soils.

Broader Impacts

  • The PIs are a microbial ecologist and an aerospace engineer, both of whom are female. Through this unique collaboration, we trained our students to tackle a large and complex project with a multi-disciplinary approach. We trained four Master’s students and 18 undergraduate students.
  • We published two journal articles, with three others in preparation. All sequence data, metadata, sampler design specifications and Ardunio code associated with published work are publicly available. We presented the results of this work through 20 presentations to scientific and public audiences. We leveraged the visibility of the helikites in urban areas to discuss our work with residents in each city, and gave two formal presentations to elementary-school students in Denver, CO.  These schools primarily serve students who are under-represented minorities in STEM (Hispanic/Latino and African American).  (Photo 6: Dissemination)
